notes.title: ICJ Statute Article 38 — Sources of International Law
notes.content: Memorize Article 38(1): treaties, custom (state practice + opinio juris), general principles; subsidiary means: judicial decisions & publicists. Most exams ask for definitions, hierarchy debates, and examples.
keyTakeaways: Treaties and custom are primary sources; judicial decisions are subsidiary.
Opinio juris distinguishes custom from mere habit.
General principles fill gaps (e.g., good faith, estoppel).

resources.title: Library of Congress — Sources of PIL

notes.title: UN Charter Core Provisions: Article 2(4) & Article 51
notes.content: Article 2(4) prohibits the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state. Article 51 preserves inherent self-defense (individual/collective) if an armed attack occurs, until the Security Council acts.
keyTakeaways: Use-of-force prohibition is a cornerstone norm (jus cogens by many scholars).
Self-defense requires necessity and proportionality; report to UNSC.
Collective self-defense requires a request/consent from the attacked state.

notes.title: Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties (1969) — Formation, Interpretation, Termination
notes.content: Defines treaty, rules on consent (signature/ratification), reservations, interpretation (good faith; ordinary meaning; context; subsequent practice), invalidity (error, fraud, corruption, coercion; conflict with jus cogens), and termination (material breach, impossibility, rebus sic stantibus).
keyTakeaways: Articles 31–33: interpretation framework favored by examiners.
Article 53/64: jus cogens invalidates conflicting treaties.
Unilateral reservations must be compatible with object and purpose.

notes.title: Montevideo Convention — Criteria of Statehood & Recognition Theories
notes.content: State qualifications: permanent population, defined territory, government, capacity for foreign relations (Art. 1). Recognition (de facto/de jure) interacts with constitutive vs. declaratory theories; exams test consequences of (non)recognition.
keyTakeaways: Montevideo criteria are widely cited though not exhaustive.
Declaratory theory: statehood exists if criteria are met; recognition is evidentiary.
Constitutive theory: recognition creates international personality.

notes.title: Jurisdiction: Territorial, Nationality, Protective, Universality & Enforcement Limits
notes.content: Different bases of prescriptive jurisdiction; enforcement generally territorial unless consent/exception. The Lotus principle highlights that what is not prohibited may be permitted, subject to specific rules and comity.
keyTakeaways: Separate prescriptive from enforcement jurisdiction in essays.
Objective territoriality covers effects felt in territory.
Lotus is often contrasted with modern treaty/custom constraints.

notes.title: ICJ: Structure, Jurisdiction, Contentious vs. Advisory
notes.content: 15 judges; states are parties in contentious cases by consent (compromissory clauses, optional clause, special agreement). Advisory opinions for UN organs. Exams ask for enforcement limits and precedential value.
keyTakeaways: Consent underpins contentious jurisdiction; advisory opinions are influential but non-binding.
Article 36 bases for jurisdiction are frequently tested.
Know examples: Corfu Channel (contentious), Wall Opinion (advisory).

notes.title: Corfu Channel (1949) — State Responsibility & Due Diligence
notes.content: ICJ held Albania responsible for mines in its territorial waters (knowledge/ due diligence). Often cited for obligations of states to not knowingly allow their territory to be used for acts contrary to rights of other states.
keyTakeaways: Establishes baseline of due diligence and obligation to notify hazards.
Illustrates evidentiary inferences (circumstantial evidence accepted).
Useful to compare with modern transboundary harm scenarios.

notes.title: Nottebohm (1955) — Effective Nationality & Diplomatic Protection
notes.content: ICJ emphasized the 'genuine link' concept regarding nationality for purposes of diplomatic protection (Liechtenstein v. Guatemala). Frequently appears in short notes and case-law identification.
keyTakeaways: Nationality for protection must reflect genuine connection.
Case limits are often misunderstood; apply carefully beyond investment claims.
Contrast with modern human rights access pathways that bypass diplomatic protection.

notes.title: UNCLOS (1982) — Maritime Zones & Navigation
notes.content: Key zones: Territorial sea (up to 12 nm), contiguous zone (24 nm), EEZ (200 nm), continental shelf (natural prolongation or 200 nm; extended shelf claims). Transit passage in straits; innocent passage in territorial sea.
keyTakeaways: Memorize zone distances and coastal vs. flag-state rights.
Hot pursuit may continue onto the high seas if initiated legally.
EEZ: sovereign rights for resources; freedoms of navigation remain.

notes.title: Geneva Conventions (1949) — IHL Basics
notes.content: Four core Conventions: wounded/sick (land), wounded/sick/shipwrecked (sea), prisoners of war, civilians. Common Article 3 applies in non-international armed conflicts. Additional Protocols expand protections.
keyTakeaways: Distinguish IAC vs. NIAC triggers and applicable rules.
POW status and civilian protections are frequent essay topics.
Grave breaches entail individual criminal responsibility.

notes.title: Articles on State Responsibility (ILC 2001) — Attribution & Reparation
notes.content: Defines internationally wrongful acts (breach + attribution), circumstances precluding wrongfulness (consent, self-defense, countermeasures, force majeure, distress, necessity), and reparation forms (restitution, compensation, satisfaction).
keyTakeaways: Article 2: elements of wrongful act; Articles 16–18: responsibility for aid/direction/coercion.
Article 21 recognizes self-defense per the UN Charter.
Article 31–39: full reparation; compensation covers financially assessable damage.

notes.title: Self-Defense & The Caroline Formula
notes.content: Customary law (Caroline incident): necessity must be 'instant, overwhelming' leaving no choice of means, and proportionality must be observed. Use with Article 51 analyses (armed attack threshold, anticipatory self-defense debates).
keyTakeaways: Necessity + proportionality are core constraints.
Anticipatory self-defense remains controversial in exam answers—argue both sides.
Report to UNSC requirement under Article 51 still applies.

notes.title: Wall Advisory Opinion (2004) & 2024 ICJ Occupation Opinion — Advisory Authority
notes.content: ICJ's 2004 advisory opinion found the construction of the wall in the OPT contrary to international law. In 2024, ICJ issued another advisory opinion on the legality of occupation and settlements. Exams ask scope, legal effect, and state obligations.
keyTakeaways: Advisory opinions are non-binding but carry great legal weight.
States are urged not to recognize unlawful situations (duty of non-recognition).
Use to illustrate interplay between IHL, human rights, and self-determination.

notes.title: Diplomatic & Consular Immunities
notes.content: Vienna Conventions (1961/1963) are standard citations. Key issues: inviolability of person/premises, immunity from criminal jurisdiction, functional necessity rationale, persona non grata.
keyTakeaways: Immunity is not impunity — waiver possible; receiving state may declare PNG.
Distinguish diplomatic vs. consular immunities.
Link to state responsibility when agents act ultra vires.

resources.title: ICJ Statute & UN Charter sections (reference)
resources.description: Context; cite specific conventions separately via course materials

notes.title: Recognition of Governments vs. States; De facto vs. De jure
notes.content: Exams frequently ask to differentiate recognition of a new state from recognition of a government, and to discuss legal effects on treaties, property, acts, and litigation standing.
keyTakeaways: Recognition of governments often hinges on effective control + constitutional legitimacy.
Non-recognition policies (e.g., Estrada doctrine) can appear in MCQs.
De facto recognition has practical but limited legal effects.

notes.title: Peaceful Settlement of Disputes
notes.content: UN Charter Chapter VI methods: negotiation, inquiry, mediation, conciliation, arbitration, judicial settlement. ICJ and arbitral tribunals are common essay directions; tie to duty to settle disputes peacefully (Art. 2(3)).
keyTakeaways: Explain when each method is appropriate; cite examples.
Security Council may recommend procedures; Chapter VII measures if threat to peace persists.
Compromissory clauses grant jurisdiction for treaty disputes.

notes.title: Human Rights vs. Humanitarian Law — Convergence & Conflicts
notes.content: IHRL applies at all times; IHL applies in armed conflict. Exams test lex specialis (IHL governing conduct of hostilities) and derogation regimes under IHRL. Use Wall Advisory Opinion to illustrate concurrent application.
keyTakeaways: Lex specialis principle guides which norm prevails in conflict.
Non-derogable rights remain in emergencies.
Extraterritorial application is contentious—argue with case law.

notes.title: Law of the Sea — Baselines, Passage & Maritime Delimitation
notes.content: Normal baselines (low-water line) vs. straight baselines; innocent passage vs. transit passage; delimitation methods and equitable principles. Recall fisheries/highly migratory stocks regime interactions.
keyTakeaways: Straits used for international navigation: transit passage (cannot be suspended).
Islands vs rocks (Art. 121) can alter EEZ claims.
Delimitation balances equidistance with equity (case-specific).

notes.title: Use of Force — Collective Security & Security Council Powers
notes.content: Security Council can determine threat to peace and authorize measures under Chapter VII (sanctions, use of force). General Assembly can recommend measures (Uniting for Peace) but not authorize force.
keyTakeaways: Differentiate Chapter VI recommendations vs. Chapter VII binding decisions.
Veto power politics is a common critical analysis theme.
Regional organizations require UNSC authorization for enforcement action (Art. 53).

notes.title: Treaty Reservations & Object-and-Purpose Test
notes.content: Reservations are unilateral statements to exclude/modify legal effect of certain provisions when signing/ratifying. They must be compatible with the object and purpose of the treaty; objections and acceptance affect inter-se relations.
keyTakeaways: Assess permissibility: text permits? object-and-purpose compatible?
Effects depend on other states' reactions; some treaties bar reservations.
Human rights bodies often police incompatible reservations.

notes.title: Theory: Monism vs. Dualism & Domestic Incorporation
notes.content: Monism: international law directly applicable domestically; Dualism: requires transformation/incorporation. Exams ask for practical implications: treaty implementation, direct effect, constitutional hierarchy.
keyTakeaways: Give country examples (examiner friendly) but focus on doctrine.
Customary international law reception varies by system.
Judicial practice can evidence monist/dualist tendencies.

resources.description: General orientation (use your jurisdiction's cases for examples)

notes.title: Exam-Favorite Short Notes: Pacta Sunt Servanda, Jus Cogens, Estoppel, Rebus Sic Stantibus
notes.content: Concise definitions with treaty hooks: Pacta sunt servanda (VCLT Art. 26); Jus cogens (Arts. 53, 64); Estoppel (general principle, case support); Rebus sic stantibus (Art. 62) with strict conditions.
keyTakeaways: Always link to VCLT provisions where applicable.
Explain strict tests to avoid abuse (e.g., fundamental change unforeseen, essential basis).
Support with case examples (e.g., Temple of Preah Vihear for estoppel in some syllabi).
